meta.yaml.description: LifeOS speculative world canon - the source of truth for all design artifacts

changes: Initial world canon extracted from WORLD.md
Documented locked vs open design decisions

setting.yaml.name: The World of 2030
setting.yaml.description: The speculative world that serves as the backdrop for all LifeOS scenarios

context.summary: AI assistance is deeply embedded in daily life. Wearable and ambient computing has matured, making context-aware systems technically feasible.

technological_landscape.name: AI Integration
technological_landscape.description: AI assistance is deeply embedded in daily life

technological_landscape.name: Ambient Computing Maturity
technological_landscape.description: Wearable/ambient computing has matured - neural smartwatches, AR glasses, smart earphones are commonplace

technological_landscape.name: App Model Showing Limits
technological_landscape.description: The app-centric model is showing its limitations - users experience fragmentation fatigue

context.design_constraint:
All LifeOS elements should feel plausible for 2030 - ambitious but not
fantastical. No magic, no hand-waving. Technology must exist or be
clearly emerging today.

problem_statement.summary:
Contemporary digital interaction demands constant cognitive labor: selecting
appropriate applications, managing context across fragmented tools, and
navigating rapid transitions between tasks. This produces digital fatigue—not
from technology use itself, but from the overhead of operating technology.
problem_statement.diagnosis:
The app-centric model treats applications as the primary interface primitive.
Users must translate goals into app selections, then operate within each app's
constraints. Context lives in the user's head. Every task switch requires
cognitive reset.

pain_points.name: Goal-to-App Translation
pain_points.description: Users must continuously translate what they want to accomplish into which app to use

pain_points.name: Context Lives in User's Head
pain_points.description: The system has no model of what the user is doing; all context management falls to the user

pain_points.name: Cognitive Reset on Task Switch
pain_points.description: Every transition between tasks requires mental overhead to reorient

pain_points.name: Fragmented Tool Landscape
pain_points.description: Managing state across dozens of apps, each with its own model of the user

solution.name: LifeOS
solution.summary: An operating system that shifts the user's job from "choose tool and operate it" to "select intent from contextually-relevant options"

capabilities.name: Adapts to Context
capabilities.description: System determines current mode based on signals (time, location, calendar, biometrics, activity)

capabilities.name: Surfaces Relevant Intents
capabilities.description: Within each mode, presents what user might want to accomplish right now

capabilities.name: Generates UI to Serve Intents
capabilities.description: When user selects intent, system constructs purpose-built interface

solution.implication:
The application layer becomes obsolete when the system can determine context,
surface relevant intents, and generate interfaces to serve them.

core_tension.summary:
Mode-intent architecture reduces cognitive load by shifting context management
and intent curation to the system. But this same shift raises a fundamental
question: where does user agency sit when the system determines context and
proposes what you might want?
core_tension.statement:
This tension between automation benefit and user agency is not incidental to
the solution—it is the central design problem for human-AI interaction. Every
design decision in a mode-intent system (how modes are determined, which intents
surface, how UI is generated) is a negotiation within this tension.

thesis.yaml.name: Bargaining with the Future
thesis.yaml.description: Automation, Agency, and the Design of Personal AI Systems
thesis.yaml.problem_statement: Digital interaction demands constant cognitive labor: selecting tools, managing fragmented context, navigating rapid transitions. This produces digital fatigue—not from technology use itself, but from the overhead of operating technology.
thesis.yaml.context: The app-centric paradigm forces users to maintain context across fragmented tools. AI assistance promises relief but creates new friction: systems that optimize on users' behalf often feel alien. Users report feeling disconnected from decisions made in their name—a loss of agency that undermines the automation benefit.
thesis.yaml.research_question: What interaction patterns enable AI systems to reduce cognitive overhead while maintaining user agency? Can automation boundaries, override mechanisms, and value alignment be made structural rather than optional?
thesis.yaml.approach:
This thesis explores these questions through LifeOS—a speculative mode-intent architecture where:

1. Context determines available actions (modes)
2. Users select from system-surfaced options (intents)
3. Decisions align with articulated values (constitutional frameworks)

The architecture makes a specific bet: that explicit automation boundaries and structured override paths can preserve agency while delivering convenience. Future self-continuity research suggests this bet may work—when users feel connected to the "future self" the system optimizes for, proactive assistance feels helpful rather than imposing.
thesis.yaml.core_tension: Every design decision negotiates the same tradeoff: present autonomy vs. future benefit. When should the system act as "future you's advocate"? How much override friction maintains agency without recreating cognitive overhead? These questions have no universal answers—only context-dependent negotiations.
thesis.yaml.scope_and_limitations:
Due to the scope of such a problem, this thesis likely won't be able to solve nor pretend to propose a solution to this tension. 

1. The tension is real, persistent, and underexplored — Neither tech-optimist framing (automation is unambiguously good) nor tech-critical framing (automation necessarily erodes agency) provides useful guidance for practitioners

2. Mode-intent provides structural vocabulary for engaging with it — Rather than abstract debates about "AI and autonomy," designers can examine specific questions: How should mode confidence thresholds work? What makes intent surfacing feel helpful vs. manipulative? Where should override friction sit?

3. LifeOS serves as reference architecture, not prescription — A sufficiently specified speculative system that enables concrete debate about design decisions, rather than speculation from scratch

The contribution is a platform for informed engagement with this tension—not a claim to have solved it.

contributions.name: Mode-intent as interaction architecture
contributions.description:
A structural framework for context-adaptive, intent-driven systems where:
- Modes define contextual solution space (system-managed)
- Intents represent user goals within that space (user-selected from surfaced options)
- Generative UI constructs purpose-built interfaces to serve selected intents

This architecture proposes that the application layer becomes obsolete when the system can determine context, surface relevant intents, and generate interfaces to serve them.

contributions.name: LifeOS as speculative design artifact
contributions.description:
A fully-realized reference system that:
- Demonstrates mode-intent architecture in concrete detail
- Makes the automation-agency tension visible and debatable at the level of specific design decisions
- Provides practitioners a platform for exploring human-AI interaction paradigms without starting from zero

devices.yaml.name: Multimodal Ecosystem
devices.yaml.description: The device ecosystem that comprises LifeOS 2030 - information and peripheral interfaces

architecture.description:
LifeOS operates through a two-tier device architecture: Information Interfaces
handle orchestration and primary interaction, while Peripheral Interfaces provide
sensing and ambient output. Peripheral devices never orchestrate.
architecture.principle:
Each device occupies a specific role in the attention spectrum. Information
interfaces handle Center-layer content (immersive, authoritative). Peripheral
interfaces handle Periphery-layer awareness (ambient, non-interrupting).

information_interfaces.description: Devices that handle orchestration and primary user interaction

devices.name: Foldable Tablet
devices.notes:
The foldable form factor provides both portable and extended workspace modes.
When folded, operates as standard phone. When unfolded, provides tablet-scale
immersive interface for attention-heavy work.

peripheral_interfaces.description: Devices that provide sensing and ambient output without orchestration
peripheral_interfaces.principle: Peripheral devices sense and output; they never orchestrate

devices.name: Neural Smartwatch

sensing.name: Real-Time State Detection
signals: Physiological state (heart rate, HRV, skin conductance)

devices.notes:
The "neural" designation refers to advanced biometric sensing capabilities
that capture physiological state for mode confidence signals. The watch serves
as the primary sensing hub for the LifeOS ecosystem.

devices.name: Glass

output.name: Embedded Knowledge
features: Information surfaced as part of real-world interaction

devices.notes:
Glass provides ambient information augmentation without demanding attention.
Overlays appear contextually and dissolve into periphery when not relevant.
The device never shows Center-layer content - that requires primary interface.

devices.name: Earphones

sensing.name: Ambient Interceptions
features: Voice transcriptions in silence (captures conversation for context)

devices.notes:
"Ultra-loose" coupling means earphones have the least orchestration dependency.
They can operate semi-independently for audio playback while still respecting
mode-based attention triage for notifications and interruptions.

attention_layer_mapping.description: How attention layers map to peripheral device display

rules.peripheral_display: Not shown on peripherals (requires primary device)
rules.rationale: Center content requires immersive attention - tablet/phone only
Peripheral devices show awareness without demanding attention
Silenced content remains invisible until contextually appropriate

device_interaction_principles.name: No Peripheral Orchestration
device_interaction_principles.description: Peripheral devices never make mode decisions or orchestrate system state
device_interaction_principles.rationale:
Orchestration requires full context synthesis and constitutional rule application.
Only information interfaces have sufficient compute and context to orchestrate safely.

device_interaction_principles.name: Distributed Sensing
device_interaction_principles.description: Multiple devices contribute different signal types for mode confidence
device_interaction_principles.rationale:
Mode confidence requires multi-modal signal fusion. Watch provides biometric context,
glass provides environmental awareness, earphones provide ambient audio, tablet
provides interaction patterns.

device_interaction_principles.name: Output Appropriateness
device_interaction_principles.description: Information is delivered through the most contextually appropriate device
device_interaction_principles.rationale:
Haptic for non-interrupting awareness (watch), ambient visual for environmental
context (glass), audio for hands-free scenarios (earphones), immersive for
attention-heavy work (tablet).

device_interaction_principles.name: Graceful Degradation
device_interaction_principles.description: LifeOS functions with any subset of devices; full ecosystem is optimal but not required
device_interaction_principles.rationale:
User may not always wear all devices. System adapts mode confidence thresholds
based on available signal sources. Reduced sensing → higher confirmation thresholds.

assumptions: Foldable displays have matured (price, durability, software)
AR glasses have achieved acceptable form factor (weight, battery, social acceptance)
Biometric sensing has advanced (non-invasive neural state indicators)
Battery technology supports all-day wear for peripheral devices
constraints: No magic - all capabilities grounded in emerging tech

system-architecture.yaml.name: LifeOS Model Architecture
system-architecture.yaml.description: Multi-Model Cooperation Stack — the full backend architecture defining how LifeOS perceives, reasons, remembers, and acts

overview.summary:
LifeOS operates as a multi-model cooperation stack where specialized subsystems
handle perception, cognition, memory, safety, and information integrity. The
Orchestrator sits at the center, routing tasks to the right specialist without
"thinking" deeply on its own. All inputs arrive at the Orchestrator and all
outputs leave from it.
overview.design_principle:
No single model does everything. The architecture distributes intelligence across
specialized layers — fast on-device models for quick decisions, large cloud models
for complex reasoning, dedicated perception models for environmental awareness —
all coordinated by the Orchestrator and checked by the Safety layer.

orchestrator.name: The Orchestrator
orchestrator.description:
The traffic controller and the only component that touches everything. It does not
"think" deeply on its own; rather, it routes tasks to the right specialist.

dependencies.perception_layer: Provides awareness of what is happening in the user's physical reality

dependencies.personal_context: Provides knowledge, values, and privacy constraints

orchestrator.flow:
All inputs (user voice, video, external news) arrive here, and all outputs
(actions, answers) leave from here. The Orchestrator:
1. Receives input from Perception (current state)
2. Retrieves context from Personal Knowledge Graph
3. Routes to appropriate reasoning model (fast or slow)
4. Validates through Safety layer
5. Checks against Personal Constitution
6. Delivers output to user through appropriate device
responsibilities: Route tasks to appropriate specialist subsystems
Apply constitutional rules to all outputs
Maintain final authority over what reaches the user

perception_layer.name: Input & Perception Layer
perception_layer.description:
Gives LifeOS "eyes and ears" to understand the user's immediate physical reality.
Converts raw sensory data into structured representations the system can reason about.

components.name: Vision-Language Models (VLM)
components.description:
Takes raw data streams and converts them into text descriptions or embeddings
the AI can understand.
outputs: Transcriptions of speech and ambient audio
components.processing:
Raw multimodal data streams are processed into structured representations that
other components can consume. The VLM bridges the gap between physical reality
and digital understanding.

components.name: World Models
components.description:
The system's "intuition" about physics and time. Predicts what will happen next
in the user's environment.
capabilities: Predicts immediate future states (e.g., "user is walking toward a door; they will likely open it")
Models physical causality and spatial relationships
components.purpose:
Provides anticipatory context so the system can prepare responses before they're
needed, enabling proactive rather than purely reactive assistance.

components.name: Perception and Grounding
components.description:
Synthesizes raw data from the VLM and predictions from the World Model into a
coherent "current state" for the Orchestrator.
components.function:
Without this component, the Orchestrator is blind to the user's physical context.
Perception and Grounding is the critical bridge that converts raw sensory data
and predictions into actionable situational awareness.

cognition_layer.name: Cognition & Safety Stack
cognition_layer.description:
Once the Orchestrator understands the situation, it needs to figure out what to do.
Thinking is split into two speeds, modeled after System 1 vs. System 2 thinking
in psychology.

components.name: Decision Making (System 1 — Fast)
components.description:
Uses small, on-device models for quick tasks. Handles things like "turn on
the lights" or "schedule a reminder." Prioritizes speed and privacy.

components.name: Large-scale Reasoning (System 2 — Slow)
components.description:
For complex problems, the system offloads to massive LLMs in the cloud that
can code, research, and plan over long horizons.
examples: Plan a travel itinerary based on my budget and these 5 articles
components.tool_use:
System 2 models can invoke external tools — search engines, calculators,
code interpreters, booking APIs — as part of their reasoning chain.

components.name: Safety, Governance, and Verification
components.description:
A critical checkpoint. Before any plan from the reasoning models is executed,
it must pass through this safety layer. The entire system relies on this to
prevent the AI from taking dangerous or unauthorized actions.

functions.name: Constraint Checking
functions.description: Validates plans against user-defined boundaries and system limits

functions.name: Red-teaming
functions.description: Actively tries to find flaws in proposed plans before execution

functions.name: Audit Logging
functions.description: Logs all decisions and actions for retrospective review

functions.name: Authorization Verification
functions.description: Ensures actions are within the scope of user consent

components.invariant:
No plan reaches execution without passing through Safety. This is the
architectural guarantee that prevents autonomous action beyond user-authorized scope.

personal_context.name: Personal Context Layer
personal_context.description:
What makes the OS "yours" rather than just a generic chatbot. Contains long-term
memory, personal values, and privacy governance.

components.name: Personal Knowledge Graph (PKG)
components.description:
Stores private data (emails, notes, history) and connects it to public knowledge.
Features provenance chips — the system remembers where it learned a fact.

features.name: Private Data Storage
features.description: Emails, notes, browsing history, conversation logs, health data

features.name: Public Knowledge Integration
features.description: Connects personal data to world knowledge for richer context

features.name: Provenance Chips
features.description:
Every stored fact carries metadata about its origin. The system knows
WHERE it learned something (e.g., "I know you like sushi because you
emailed John about it on Tuesday").
features.purpose:
Provenance enables trust, auditability, and the ability to retract
knowledge when sources are found unreliable.

features.name: Relationship Mapping
features.description: Models connections between people, places, events, and preferences

components.flow:
The Orchestrator queries the PKG for relevant context before making decisions.
The PKG provides the personalized information that transforms generic AI
responses into contextually appropriate assistance.

components.name: Personal Constitution
components.description:
Contains explicit rules and values articulated by the user. The Orchestrator
checks every decision against this Constitution to ensure alignment with the
user's specific principles.
examples: Never book flights on a Tuesday
No work notifications during family dinner
components.function:
The Constitution is not a preference list — it is an operational ruleset that
actively constrains system behavior. Constitutional rules override convenience
optimizations.

components.name: Privacy
components.description:
A strict governance layer that manages data retention and ensures sensitive
memories are handled appropriately.

capabilities.name: Data Retention (TTLs)
capabilities.description: Time-to-live policies that automatically expire sensitive data

capabilities.name: Redaction
capabilities.description: Removes sensitive information from data before storage or sharing

capabilities.name: Deletion Policies
capabilities.description: Ensures data is permanently removed when retention period expires

capabilities.name: Access Control
capabilities.description: Governs which components can access which categories of personal data

information_integrity.name: Information Integrity Stack
information_integrity.description:
Responsible for ingesting the chaotic external world and cleaning it before it
touches personal data. Ensures information quality and alignment with user values.

components.name: External Provider Data
components.description:
The raw, unfiltered information from the outside world. These providers have
business models and agendas — they cannot directly reach the user.

sources.name: Other Providers
sources.description: Any external data source the system integrates with

components.name: Verification & Provenance
components.description:
Before external data reaches the user, it passes through deepfake detection
and source authentication. Verifies if the information is real.

capabilities.name: Source Authentication
capabilities.description: Verifies the origin and authority of information sources

capabilities.name: Fact Verification
capabilities.description: Cross-references claims against trusted knowledge bases

capabilities.name: Provenance Tracking
capabilities.description: Maintains chain of custody for information from source to user

components.name: Constitutional Filtering
components.description:
Filters verified data based on the user's Personal Constitution. Ensures
external information aligns with user-articulated values.
examples: Filtering clickbait when Constitution requests factual reporting
Removing biased news when user values neutral perspectives
Blocking engagement-optimized content that conflicts with attention values
components.flow:
Verified external data → Constitutional rule matching → Filtered data that
aligns with user values → Passed to Information Augmentation

components.name: Information Augmentation (RAG)
components.description:
Retrieval-Augmented Generation — matches the user's current query with verified
external information and feeds contextualized results to the Orchestrator.
components.function:
Combines verified external data with personal context to produce relevant,
trustworthy, and personalized information for the Orchestrator to present.
components.flow:
User query → Retrieve relevant verified external data → Augment with personal
context → Generate contextualized response → Deliver to Orchestrator

data_flow.description:
The complete path from user request to system response, demonstrating how all
layers cooperate.

example.scenario: User asks: Plan a dinner for my anniversary.

steps.name: User Request
steps.description: Voice or text input arrives at the Orchestrator

steps.name: Perception
steps.description: VLM sees user is in their kitchen; World Model knows it's evening

steps.name: Context Retrieval
steps.description:
Orchestrator pings the Personal Knowledge Graph to recall anniversary date
and partner's allergies

steps.name: External Search
steps.description:
Searches External Provider Data for restaurants. Verification layer removes
fake reviews; Constitutional Filtering removes restaurants that don't match
dietary values.

steps.name: Reasoning
steps.description: Large-scale Reasoning model creates a plan: "Book table at X, order flowers from Y."

steps.name: Safety Check
steps.description: Safety module verifies the plan (e.g., checks if restaurant is within budget limits)

steps.name: Execution
steps.description: Decision Making model executes the booking tool

steps.name: Output
steps.description: Orchestrator displays the confirmation on the user's phone

cross_cutting.name: Privacy by Design
cross_cutting.description:
Privacy is not an afterthought — it is enforced at every layer. On-device
processing is preferred. Cloud processing requires justification. Personal
data never leaves the Privacy vault without governance checks.

cross_cutting.name: Constitutional Alignment Throughout
cross_cutting.description:
The Personal Constitution is not checked at one point — it influences decisions
at multiple layers: mode activation, intent surfacing, information filtering,
and action execution.

cross_cutting.name: Full Auditability
cross_cutting.description:
Every decision, from perception interpretation to action execution, is logged
and available for retrospective review through the Dashboard. The system can
always explain why it did what it did.

cross_cutting.name: Graceful Degradation
cross_cutting.description:
When cloud services are unavailable, the system falls back to on-device
capabilities (System 1). When perception is limited (fewer devices), the
system raises confirmation thresholds. No single component failure should
render the system useless.

assumptions: VLMs capable of real-time multimodal processing exist (trajectory from GPT-4V, Gemini)
On-device SLMs are sufficient for routine tasks (trajectory from Apple Intelligence, Gemma)
Cloud LLMs have reliable tool-use and planning (trajectory from current agent frameworks)
RAG pipelines are mature and production-ready (already emerging in 2024-2025)
Deepfake detection is viable but imperfect (arms race continues)
World models for everyday scenarios are feasible (trajectory from video prediction models)
constraints: No perfect deepfake detection (probabilistic, not certain)
Network connectivity required for System 2 reasoning
Privacy governance requires legal/regulatory framework (GDPR descendants)

provider-integration.yaml.name: Provider Integration Model
provider-integration.yaml.description: The core mechanism that replaces the application paradigm with provider-orchestrator-user flow

overview.summary:
The Provider Integration Model is the fundamental architectural innovation that makes
the application layer obsolete. Instead of apps as interfaces, brands and services
become data providers that feed into the Information Integrity Stack, which the
Orchestrator then synthesizes and presents through contextually appropriate intents.
overview.paradigm_shift:
Traditional computing: User → App Selection → App Interface → Service
LifeOS computing: Provider → Information Integrity → Orchestrator → Intent → User

The critical difference: In LifeOS, providers cannot directly reach users. All
information flows through integrity verification and constitutional filtering before
the Orchestrator decides what reaches the user and how.

three_stage_flow.description:
Every piece of external information follows this path from provider to user.
No shortcuts, no direct access, no bypassing the integrity layer.

stage_1_providers.name: External Providers Supply Raw Data
stage_1_providers.description:
Brands and services (Spotify, NYT, WhatsApp, Maps, etc.) provide data, APIs,
and capabilities. They have business models and agendas, but cannot directly
reach the user.
characteristics: Business models may conflict with user goals
Must integrate via provider API specification

stage_2_information_integrity.name: Information Integrity Stack Filters & Verifies
stage_2_information_integrity.description:
Before external data reaches the user, it passes through verification and
constitutional filtering. This is the trust mechanism that protects users
from manipulation, misinformation, and engagement optimization.

responsibilities.name: Source Authentication
responsibilities.description: Verifies origin and authority of information sources

responsibilities.name: Fact Verification
responsibilities.description: Cross-references claims against trusted knowledge bases
responsibilities.scope: Factual claims only, not opinions or subjective content

responsibilities.name: Provenance Tracking
responsibilities.description: Maintains chain of custody from source to user
responsibilities.purpose: Enables trust, auditability, retraction of unreliable sources

components.name: Constitutional Filtering
components.description:
Filters verified data based on user's Personal Constitution. This is not
censorship—it's alignment with explicitly articulated user values.

examples.constitution_rule: Prioritize factual reporting over opinion pieces
examples.filter_behavior: De-prioritize editorial content, surface news analysis
Remove headlines with emotional manipulation patterns
Boost local options in commerce/dining recommendations

examples.constitution_rule: Limit social media during work hours
examples.filter_behavior: Hold social content in Silence during Work mode

principles: User controls the rules (not the system, not providers)
Rules are explicit and auditable (not hidden algorithmic preferences)
Filtering respects urgency (emergency content pierces filters)
User can always request held content (transparency, not paternalism)

components.name: Information Augmentation (RAG)
components.description:
Retrieval-Augmented Generation matches current query with verified external
data and augments it with personal context from the PKG.
process: Augment with personal context (preferences, history, relationships)

stage_3_orchestrator.name: Orchestrator Generates Contextual UI & Intents
stage_3_orchestrator.description:
The Orchestrator has final authority over what reaches users and how. It
synthesizes verified information, applies constitutional rules, and generates
purpose-built interfaces based on current mode and available intents.

responsibilities.name: Mode Determination
responsibilities.description: Assesses current context to activate appropriate mode

responsibilities.name: Intent Surfacing
responsibilities.description: Presents relevant actions available in current mode

responsibilities.name: Attention Triage
responsibilities.description: Routes information to Center, Periphery, or Silence

responsibilities.name: UI Generation
responsibilities.description: Constructs purpose-built interface to serve selected intent

responsibilities.name: Multi-Provider Synthesis
responsibilities.description: Combines data from multiple providers in single intent
responsibilities.example:
Navigation intent may synthesize: Maps (route), Calendar (destination),
Weather (conditions), Contacts (meeting attendees), Messaging (ETA sharing)

app_obsolescence.description:
When the orchestrator can determine context, surface relevant capabilities,
generate purpose-built interfaces, and filter manipulation—the app as
intermediary is no longer necessary.

characteristics.name: User selects app, then figures out task
General-purpose tool
characteristics.problem: One interface tries to serve many use cases

characteristics.name: Business model may conflict with user goals
Context lives in user's head
characteristics.problem: User must maintain mental model across fragmented tools

characteristics.name: User selects intent based on goal
characteristics.benefit: Direct goal accomplishment, no app selection overhead

characteristics.name: Specific goal accomplishment
characteristics.benefit: Purpose-built interface for this moment's task

characteristics.name: Bounded with completion designed in
characteristics.benefit: Clear exit, no infinite engagement traps

provider_examples.name: Spotify
provider_examples.traditional_flow:
1. User decides they want music
2. Opens Spotify app
3. Browses playlists or searches
4. Selects music and plays
5. App persists, can distract with recommendations
provider_examples.lifeos_flow:
1. Music intent surfaces in Rest mode (system detected context)
2. Orchestrator queries Spotify provider for user's library
3. Constitutional filter applies listening preferences
4. Playback UI generated with relevant playlists
5. Intent completes when user starts playback or exits
provider_examples.key_difference:
Spotify becomes a music library provider, not an interface. The Orchestrator
presents music options when contextually appropriate, filtered by user's
listening values.

provider_examples.name: New York Times
provider_examples.traditional_flow:
1. User opens NYT app (or checks notifications)
2. Scrolls through feed
3. Engagement-optimized algorithm surfaces content
4. No alignment check with user's information diet values
5. Potential for doomscrolling, outrage engagement
provider_examples.lifeos_flow:
1. News surfaces in Periphery during morning routine
2. Verification layer validates sources and checks for manipulation
3. Constitutional filter removes clickbait, applies reading preferences
4. Orchestrator generates summary matching user's information diet
5. Bounded reading experience with clear completion
provider_examples.key_difference:
NYT provides articles, but cannot control presentation or force engagement
patterns. Orchestrator filters for quality journalism aligned with user's
constitutional values.

provider_examples.name: Google Maps
provider_examples.traditional_flow:
1. User realizes they need to navigate somewhere
2. Opens Maps app
3. Enters destination manually
4. Reviews route options
5. Starts navigation
provider_examples.lifeos_flow:
1. Navigation mode auto-activates when calendar event approaches
2. Maps provider supplies route data to event location
3. Orchestrator synthesizes: route, traffic, weather, meeting context
4. Navigation intent presented in Center (highest attention)
5. Automatic transition to next mode upon arrival
provider_examples.key_difference:
Maps becomes a route data provider. The system knows where you're going
(from calendar) and surfaces navigation proactively, not reactively.

provider_examples.name: WhatsApp
provider_examples.traditional_flow:
1. Notification arrives (app decides when to interrupt)
2. User context-switches to check message
3. Responds in app
4. Returns to previous task (with cognitive reset overhead)
provider_examples.lifeos_flow:
1. Message arrives from WhatsApp provider
2. Constitutional triage determines appropriate layer:
   - Center: Emergency contacts, awaited replies
   - Periphery: Friend messages during work
   - Silence: Group chats during Focus mode
3. Message surfaces in current mode context when appropriate
4. Response intent available without full context switch
provider_examples.key_difference:
WhatsApp provides messages but cannot demand attention. Orchestrator
applies constitutional rules to determine when and how messages surface.

user_benefits.name: No Context Switching
user_benefits.description:
System maintains context across all data sources. User doesn't mentally switch
between apps—they select intents within coherent modes. The cognitive overhead
of app selection and context management is eliminated.

user_benefits.name: Protected from Manipulation
user_benefits.description:
Information Integrity layer blocks dark patterns, engagement optimization, and
algorithmic manipulation before it reaches users. Constitutional filtering ensures
provider business models don't override user wellbeing.

user_benefits.name: Constitutional Alignment
user_benefits.description:
Every piece of information filtered through Personal Constitution. System behavior
aligns with explicitly articulated user values, not provider incentives or default
engagement metrics.

user_benefits.name: Attention-Aware Triage
user_benefits.description:
Information routed to Center, Periphery, or Silence based on current mode and
constitutional rules—not notification counts or engagement optimization. User's
attention is treated as valuable, not extractable.

user_benefits.name: Purpose-Built Interfaces
user_benefits.description:
UI generated to serve specific intent in current mode, not general-purpose app.
Bounded experiences with clear completion conditions, not infinite feeds designed
for maximum time-on-platform.

user_benefits.name: Multi-Provider Synthesis
user_benefits.description:
Orchestrator can combine data from multiple providers in a single intent—no manual
app switching required. Navigation can include calendar, weather, traffic, contacts,
and messaging in one coherent experience.

provider_integration_requirements.description:
For a service to integrate as a provider in LifeOS, it must meet these requirements.
This ensures quality, security, and alignment with LifeOS principles.

technical_requirements.name: Provider API Specification
technical_requirements.description: Well-documented API for data access and action execution

technical_requirements.name: Secure Authentication
technical_requirements.description: OAuth 2.0 or equivalent secure auth mechanism

technical_requirements.name: Rate Limiting & Quotas
technical_requirements.description: Documented API limits to prevent abuse
technical_requirements.purpose: Protects both provider infrastructure and user experience

technical_requirements.name: Structured Data Schema
technical_requirements.description: Clear schema for all data types returned

integrity_requirements.name: Provenance Metadata
integrity_requirements.description: Every piece of data carries source information

integrity_requirements.name: Content Authenticity Indicators
integrity_requirements.description: Signals for AI-generated or manipulated content

integrity_requirements.name: Real-time Update Mechanism
integrity_requirements.description: Webhooks or push notifications for timely data

governance_requirements.name: Data Minimization
governance_requirements.description: Providers should only request necessary data
governance_requirements.principle: Collect minimum viable data for service provision

governance_requirements.name: Explicit User Consent
governance_requirements.description: Users approve each provider integration explicitly

governance_requirements.name: Audit Trail
governance_requirements.description: All provider actions logged for retrospective review

provider_neutrality.description:
The Orchestrator must remain neutral toward providers. No preferential
treatment, no pay-to-surface. Provider data competes on constitutional
alignment and relevance, not business relationships.

graceful-degradation.description:
When a provider is unavailable (API down, rate limited, user revoked access),
the system must gracefully degrade. Other providers may compensate, or the
Orchestrator may surface alternative intents.

provider_competition.description:
Multiple providers can serve the same category (e.g., multiple music streaming
services). The Orchestrator selects based on user preferences, availability,
and constitutional alignment—not exclusivity deals.

intent_portability.description:
Intents are provider-agnostic where possible. "Play music" shouldn't be
Spotify-specific—it should work with any music provider the user has connected.

open_questions.question: How do providers sustain business models without direct user attention?
open_questions.notes:
Traditional apps monetize attention (ads, engagement). In LifeOS, providers
supply data but don't control presentation. Possible models: subscription
(Spotify), transaction fees (Uber), data licensing to Orchestrator. This is
an unresolved economic question.

open_questions.question: What incentivizes providers to integrate if they lose interface control?
open_questions.notes:
Providers lose ability to manipulate attention but gain: reduced app maintenance,
access to contextual presentation, integration with other services. The value
proposition needs validation.

open_questions.question: How reliable can verification/deepfake detection be by 2030?
open_questions.notes:
Verification is an ongoing arms race. The system should be transparent about
confidence levels rather than presenting certainty. "This source is verified"
vs. "This source claims to be X but verification failed."

assumptions: Providers willing to adapt to platform model (like apps adapted to iOS/Android)
API standards mature enough for consistent integration
Verification technology viable but imperfect (probabilistic confidence)
Users value constitutional filtering over direct app control
Economic models emerge that sustain providers without direct attention monetization
constraints: No perfect deepfake detection (arms race continues)
Some services may resist giving up interface control
Network effects favor incumbent apps initially

questions.name: Constitutional Conflict
questions.question: How does the system handle values that contradict in specific scenarios?
questions.notes:
Example: "don't miss important things" vs "work shouldn't bleed into everything"
when important work message arrives during family dinner.

questions.name: Urgency Determination
questions.question: What pierces Silence? Who decides what's urgent?
questions.notes:
Need to define urgency signals and how they interact with
constitutional values. User-defined vs system-inferred urgency.

domains/modes.yaml.name: Mode Framework
domains/modes.yaml.description: Modes are fluid, contextual stances that emerge from Life Domains. They are not fixed categories but dynamic responses to the user's current situation within a domain.

framework_flow.description:
The Mode–Intent Framework follows a four-stage flow:
1. Life Domain - The 7 fundamental categories of human activity
2. Mode - A fluid, contextual stance activated within a domain
3. Intent - Available actions surfaced by the active mode
4. UI - Dynamically generated interface for the selected intent
framework_flow.key_principle:
Modes are NOT fixed. Mode names emerge naturally from the intersection of 
a Life Domain and the user's current situation. Each domain can spawn 
countless contextual modes based on what the user is doing.

mode_fluidity.description:
Unlike traditional app categories, modes are fluid and emerge from context.
A mode name like "Thesis Discussion" or "Quick Check-in" emerges naturally 
from the intersection of domain and situation.

communication_connection.note: These are not fixed modes—they emerge from the context within this domain

sections.name: Activation Model
sections.description: How modes are entered based on confidence signals

mechanics.confidence_based_entry:
Multiple context signals contribute to confidence score.
Each signal has weight based on reliability and relevance.
Confidence must exceed threshold for activation.

thresholds.behavior: System suggests mode: 'Looks like you're entering Focus. Confirm?'
System enters mode automatically, explanation available
Hysteresis - must drop below this to exit

mechanics.hysteresis_rationale:
Different thresholds for entry vs. exit prevents oscillation.
Once in a mode, stay until clearly no longer appropriate.

sections.name: Exit Design
sections.description: How users exit modes - always possible, with informational friction
sections.invariant: Exit is always possible. User is never locked into a mode.
friction_design: Exit has friction, but friction is informational, not obstructive
Friction surfaces trade-offs: 'This is what you're leaving; this is what changes'
Friction never punishes, shames, or creates dead ends
sections.template:
You're leaving [Mode Name].

What changes:
- [Specific change 1]
- [Specific change 2]
- [What was held will become active]

Why you might stay:
- [Contextual reason]
- [Progress indicator if applicable]

[Exit anyway]  [Stay in mode]

sections.name: Mode Collision
sections.description: What happens when two modes have equal or near-equal confidence

candidate_approaches.name: Recency bias
candidate_approaches.description: Stay in current mode unless new mode clearly dominant

sections.name: Domain-Mode Relationship
sections.description: How life domains inform mode generation

key_distinctions.mode: Contextual stance at a moment in time (temporal)

invariants: A single mode can span multiple domains (Focus Mode applies to Work AND Personal Fulfillment)
A single domain can spawn countless modes (Communication domain → Thesis Discussion, Catch-up, Messaging, etc.)
Mode names are not fixed—they emerge from context
Domain information informs mode confidence signals and triage rules

defined_modes.name: Navigation Mode
defined_modes.purpose: Active when user is traveling to a destination. Optimizes for wayfinding while protecting attention.
activation_triggers: Calendar event with different location approaching

defined_modes.name: Focus Mode
defined_modes.purpose: Active during deep work requiring sustained attention. Maximizes protection from interruption.
activation_triggers: Work pattern signals (specific apps, typing patterns)

defined_modes.name: Social Mode
defined_modes.purpose: Active during interpersonal interaction. Optimizes for presence with people.

domains/intents.yaml.name: Intent Framework
domains/intents.yaml.description: Intents are available actions surfaced by the active mode. They represent what the user can DO within their current contextual stance.

framework_position.description:
In the Domain → Mode → Intent → UI flow, Intents are the third stage:
1. Life Domain - Informs the context category
2. Mode - Determines the user's stance and filters available actions
3. Intent - User-selected action from mode-appropriate options
4. UI - Dynamically generated interface for the selected intent
key_invariants: Available intents are constrained by the current mode
Each intent has bounded scope with designed completion
Intents generate purpose-built UI, not generic app interfaces

sections.name: Intent Requirements
sections.description: Every intent must meet these requirements

requirements.name: Bounded Scope
requirements.description: What the intent includes and explicitly excludes

requirements.name: Mode Constraints
requirements.description: Which modes this intent is available in

sections.rationale:
Bounded experiences, not infinite feeds. Every intent has designed
completion, not endless engagement.

sections.name: Intent vs. App Distinction
sections.description: How intents differ from traditional apps

comparison.traditional_app: User selects app, then figures out task
comparison.lifeos_intent: User selects intent based on goal

comparison.traditional_app: Business model may conflict with user goals

sections.name: Intent Inheritance Across Modes
sections.description: Can intents span mode transitions, or do they terminate on mode exit?

candidate_approaches.name: Graceful handoff
candidate_approaches.description: Intent pauses, can resume if mode re-entered

candidate_approaches.name: Intent completion priority
candidate_approaches.description: Mode exit blocked until intent completes, with override

sections.name: Intent-Mode Relationship
sections.description: How modes surface and constrain intents

mechanics.filtering:
The current mode acts as a filter over the universe of possible intents.
Only intents relevant to the mode's purpose are surfaced to the user.
mechanics.surfacing:
When a mode is active, it determines which intents appear prominent (Center),
which are available but de-emphasized (Periphery), and which are hidden (Silence).
mechanics.generation:
Once a user selects an intent, the orchestrator generates a purpose-built
interface that serves that specific intent—not a generic app UI.

domains/navigation-mobility.yaml.name: Navigation & Mobility
domains/navigation-mobility.yaml.description: Getting from place to place, spatial awareness, movement through physical world

sections.title: Core Activities
sections.content:
- Wayfinding and navigation to destinations
- Route planning and optimization
- Spatial awareness and orientation
- Movement through physical spaces
- Travel coordination and logistics
- Real-time location awareness

sections.title: Key Interactions
sections.content:
- Initiating navigation to a destination
- Monitoring progress and ETA
- Adapting to route changes
- Coordinating arrival timing
- Managing transportation options

sections.title: Design Considerations
sections.content:
- Attention must remain on physical environment for safety
- Time pressure varies (late for meeting vs. casual travel)
- Familiarity affects cognitive load (known vs. unknown routes)
- Interruptions during navigation can be dangerous
- Need for glanceable, minimal-attention interfaces

domains/communication-connection.yaml.name: Communication & Connection
domains/communication-connection.yaml.description: Personal relationships, staying in touch, social coordination, meaningful connection

sections.title: Core Activities
sections.content:
- Maintaining personal relationships
- Synchronous communication (calls, face-to-face)
- Asynchronous communication (messaging, email)
- Social coordination and planning
- Building and deepening connections
- Presence and active listening

sections.title: Key Interactions
sections.content:
- Responding to messages and communications
- Initiating contact with others
- Managing availability and boundaries
- Coordinating social activities
- Being present during in-person interactions

sections.title: Design Considerations
sections.content:
- Quality of connection vs. quantity of interactions
- Presence matters: digital interruptions erode social quality
- Response urgency is context-dependent
- Different relationships have different communication norms
- Synchronous moments deserve protection from asynchronous demands
- Connection depth requires sustained attention

domains/entertainment-media.yaml.name: Entertainment & Media
domains/entertainment-media.yaml.description: Content consumption, news, games, entertainment, staying informed, cultural participation

sections.title: Core Activities
sections.content:
- Consuming media content (video, audio, text)
- Playing games and interactive entertainment
- Following news and current events
- Exploring cultural content
- Discovering new content
- Social media engagement

sections.title: Key Interactions
sections.content:
- Browsing and discovering content
- Active consumption (watching, reading, listening)
- Engagement with content (commenting, sharing)
- Managing subscriptions and feeds
- Balancing information diet

sections.title: Design Considerations
sections.content:
- Infinite feeds designed for maximum engagement
- Boundary between intentional consumption and passive scrolling
- News anxiety and information overload
- Algorithmic recommendations vs. user-directed exploration
- Completion conditions often absent by design
- Time easily lost to auto-play and endless content
- Need for intentional stopping points

domains/life-management.yaml.name: Life Management
domains/life-management.yaml.description: Life logistics, household tasks, finances, scheduling, admin work, keeping things running

sections.title: Core Activities
sections.content:
- Calendar and schedule management
- Financial tracking and bill payment
- Household task coordination
- Administrative paperwork
- Errand planning and execution
- Maintenance and upkeep
- Life logistics coordination

sections.title: Key Interactions
sections.content:
- Adding and reviewing calendar events
- Managing to-do lists and tasks
- Tracking expenses and budgets
- Coordinating household responsibilities
- Processing administrative tasks
- Planning and executing errands

sections.title: Design Considerations
sections.content:
- High cognitive overhead from fragmented systems
- Many small decisions throughout the day
- Interruptions break task flow
- Planning requires focus, execution can be automated
- Cognitive load from remembering vs. being reminded
- Coordination across multiple people and systems
- Balance between control and delegation

domains/work-career.yaml.name: Work & Career
domains/work-career.yaml.description: Professional responsibilities, collaboration, career development, workplace dynamics

sections.title: Core Activities
sections.content:
- Executing professional tasks and projects
- Collaboration with colleagues
- Meetings and synchronous work
- Deep focus work
- Professional communication
- Career development and learning
- Strategic planning

sections.title: Key Interactions
sections.content:
- Managing work communications
- Attending and scheduling meetings
- Executing focused work sessions
- Coordinating with team members
- Tracking projects and deliverables
- Professional learning and skill development

sections.title: Design Considerations
sections.content:
- Deep work requires sustained attention blocks
- Context switching is costly
- Work-life boundaries need active protection
- Different work modes (focus, collaboration, admin)
- Urgency vs. importance often conflated
- Always-on culture creates burnout
- Asynchronous vs. synchronous collaboration trade-offs
- Career development easily deprioritized

domains/health-wellness.yaml.name: Health & Wellness
domains/health-wellness.yaml.description: Physical health, mental wellbeing, rest, recovery, body awareness

sections.title: Core Activities
sections.content:
- Physical exercise and movement
- Sleep and rest
- Nutrition and eating
- Mental health and stress management
- Medical care and health monitoring
- Recovery and downtime
- Body awareness and physiological state

sections.title: Key Interactions
sections.content:
- Monitoring health metrics
- Planning and executing exercise
- Managing sleep schedules
- Stress awareness and intervention
- Medical appointments and care
- Mindfulness and relaxation practices

sections.title: Design Considerations
sections.content:
- Health data is highly personal and sensitive
- Physiological state affects all other domains
- Recovery time is productive time
- Stress response can be detected but requires nuanced interpretation
- Gamification can be motivating or anxiety-inducing
- Rest is active wellbeing, not absence of productivity
- Mental health is as important as physical health
- Body awareness provides context for all other activities

domains/personal-fulfillment.yaml.name: Personal Fulfillment
domains/personal-fulfillment.yaml.description: Creative expression, hobbies, interests, learning for curiosity, personal projects, skill development, self-reflection, personal growth, meaning-making

sections.title: Core Activities
sections.content:
- Creative expression and artistic pursuits
- Hobby engagement and exploration
- Learning driven by curiosity (not career)
- Personal projects and passion work
- Skill development for intrinsic satisfaction
- Self-reflection and journaling
- Personal growth and identity exploration
- Meaning-making and purpose discovery
- Intellectual curiosity and deep exploration

sections.title: Key Interactions
sections.content:
- Dedicating time to creative work
- Exploring new interests and hobbies
- Engaging in reflective practices
- Pursuing learning for its own sake
- Working on personal projects
- Developing skills outside professional context

sections.title: Design Considerations
sections.content:
- Easily deprioritized under productivity pressure
- Requires protected time without interruption
- No external deadlines makes scheduling difficult
- Value is intrinsic, not instrumental
- Flow states require sustained attention
- Exploration benefits from low-stakes experimentation
- Reflection requires spaciousness and quiet
- Often the first domain sacrificed when busy
- Critical for long-term wellbeing and identity
- Cannot be optimized without losing its essence
